Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Cam [safe.trade]> I have a weird question about forking due to high hash devices (ASICS fpgas etc) if they gain enough hash quickly enough can’t they basically prevent the fork because they have the most hash? Or it ends up like BSV vs ABC?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Cam [safe.trade]> With an actual fork that loses value on both sides?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <blackjok3r> Yes ... but in this case its a small group of people. you need the buying power for the coins on the fork. SV has big big money behind it, which is why its working out for them.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> And the fork without a dev team is basically useless.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Cam [safe.trade]> Ok. I thought so but just hadn’t confirmed my thoughts

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Cam [safe.trade]> @zpajk good point

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <blackjok3r> Forking verus without Mike would be a pretty poor plan 😃

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Cam [safe.trade]> Although I’m kind of a “the rule of the code is the rule” guy, and I don’t like seeing constant forks. Improvement is good, but not a constant battle. Kind of evolution vs revolution

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <blackjok3r> I've stated my opinion on it ... but in the end its mikes desision... Maybe only one fork is required . In that case its probably fine, but just making a better FPGA that is open source is the best plan of action, and then everyone can constantly imporve it. Trying to make the coin CPU and GPU only is a fools errand.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> thanks @zpajk

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @Cam [safe.trade] actually, Verus Proof of Power is immune to 51% hash attacks, and then there is dPoW. i suspect they go to other coins for a while, but we will see

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Takoy_Nahal> I am sure Mike and his team will solve this problem, our task is to support him

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> I would think Verus needs to grow a bigger community of "invested" users in this early stage, and therefore taking miners as example. You're more likely to gather more users as CPU/GPU miners at this point, because FPGAs aren't readily available to a large number of people. If there's not a plan where they all co-exist you'll end up with only a few FPGAs, disencouraging CPU/GPU. Moving forward with larger exchanges and what not, we'll surely be seeing other invested users but as traders/holders/staking, which may render this predicament obsolete.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @blackjok3r i agree with you on the open hardware transition, but i'm not convinced it's a fools errand. i think our approach has a lot of reasons it could work, and we could also have open hardware that is faster without knocking out casual mining completely. we'll see on that too. if we achieve it, i would see no reason to fork again for the algorithm

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Takoy_Nahal> @zpajk You forget about the large community of POS miners who stay with Verus for a long time. POS is available to everyone, and it is wonderful that Verus cannot be completely controlled by a narrow circle of people. Fork at which there will be an advantage for the CPU miners will add more decentralization

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> Didn't forget, I meant POS-investors will be increased with the latter part; by finding investors/stakers through bigger exchanges.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Takoy_Nahal> exactly

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> Not of course simple math. Exchanges don't necessarily equal more investors, that has to do with marketing, but still.
